repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Works locally for me so far. Tested with steps from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11282.

Related: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/4349

comment_data.body:
normally we put this on `TUIData` struct, then access it in `tui_term_osc_cmd` via the `ui->data` pointer. Probably the other `static bool` items here could have that treatment, but not worth changing since https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/10071 will change this stuff.

And then the assignment could be put in `terminfo_start`.
There should be no need to hardcode specifically this sequence form in the ui event itself, rather we should have a generic `term_output` event which just forwards any string unmodified.
This was marked as resolved, but looks unchanged.
You said _not worth changing because https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/10071 will change this_? I'll change it.
"Not worth changing" was referring to `did_user_set_dimensions` et al. Whereas `tmux` is being changed already in this PR, so it should not continue the pattern.
this is already in `api/private/helpers.h`. Why's it needed here?
I removed it anyway in the latest version, because a) it'd need `strlen()` instead of `sizeof` and b) I can pass a different size (-1 for the newline).

this won't set a value in the outer scope (except maybe by `debug.setupvalue` ?). Try this instead:

```lua
    local received = {}

    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
      table.insert(received, command)
    end

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_data.body:
I believe the local handler isn't even called.

```diff
diff --git i/test/functional/terminal/tui_spec.lua w/test/functional/terminal/tui_spec.lua
index db0a7382b..eef43b0c6 100644
--- i/test/functional/terminal/tui_spec.lua
+++ w/test/functional/terminal/tui_spec.lua
@@ -836,6 +836,7 @@ describe('TUI', function()
     local received = {}

     screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      print('LOCAL')
       table.insert(received, command)
     end

diff --git i/test/functional/ui/screen.lua w/test/functional/ui/screen.lua
index 25bb2309f..f92cec4ea 100644
--- i/test/functional/ui/screen.lua
+++ w/test/functional/ui/screen.lua
@@ -1538,6 +1538,7 @@ function Screen:_attr_index(attrs, attr)
 end

 function Screen:_handle_term_unhandled(command)
+  print('GLOBAL')
 end

 return Screen
```

When applying this diff, running `TEST_FILTER=outer TEST_FILE=test/functional/terminal/tui_spec.lua make functionaltest` spits out `GLOBAL` 3 times, but no `LOCAL` at all.

So, is this even the correct way to overwrite a function from `screen.lua`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_data.body:
> this won't set a value in the outer scope (except maybe by debug.setupvalue ?). Try this instead:

Upvales are mutable in lua, so this is not a problem.

Rather the problem here is using function instead of method syntax, which is needed even for "local" override. The correct way would be

```
function screen:_handle_term_unhandled(command)
    table.insert(received, command)
end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_data.body:
You must run the event loop in order for handlers to be called. So this needs to be 
```
screen:expect{condition=function()
  eq(unknown_dcs_seq, received)
end}
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command
+    end
+
+    local unknown_dcs_seq = '\033Pblah\033\\'
+    feed_data(unknown_dcs_seq)
+    eq(unknown_dcs_seq, received)

comment_data.body:
Same issue after applying these two fixes: `received` is empty. `screen:_handle_term_unhandled()` still isn't triggered somehow (at least a debug output is not printed).

I pushed the current version in case you want to check it out directly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_data.body: Is it worth testing that with `$TMUX` set, we get the tmux-wrapped escape code?
Yup, I guess we could simply faking it by using `let $TMUX = 'nonempty'`. After we get the tests to work at all. :)

I've attempted to debug this myself - `term_unhandled_dcs` / `term_unhandled_osc` is called with the right string, but on the lua side we only get an empty string passed into `screen:_handle_term_unhandled`. I suspect there's some marshalling problem.

I suspected that because of the async nature, freeing the string may have been problematic, but I believe we copy the argument before passing it to the lua side, so that's not the problem.

(also - how can we get debug output from tests, without resorting to things like `eq("debug output here", variable_i_want_to_observe)` ?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_data.body:
> (also - how can we get debug output from tests, without resorting to things like `eq("debug output here", variable_i_want_to_observe)` ?)

Currently we don't have a convenient logging function in Lua-land, though it's very much wanted. From C one can use ELOG and that will show up in NVIM_LOG_FILE (which is tail'd by the test runner).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -831,6 +831,22 @@ describe('TUI', function()
       {3:-- TERMINAL --}                                    |
     ]=])
   end)
+
+  it('forwards unknown DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal', function()
+    local received
+
+    screen._handle_term_unhandled = function(command)
+      received = command

comment_regular_data.body: Either we limit this PR to DCS/OSC for the moment, or we'll close it, since LeoNerd wants to revamp fallback handler anyway in the future.

> Either we limit this PR to DCS/OSC for the moment

That's fine. There should be a basic test though, so we at least have something describing the "shape" of the behavior for when we revisit this after a later libvterm update.

It's definitely worth merging this after that. Else the work here will get lost in time :)

Current state:

The C side looks fine to me and I actually tested it with the `printf '\033]1337;SetUserVar=foo=%s\007' "$(base64 <<< "blah" | tr -d '\n')"` example from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11282 inside and outside of tmux.

But running the actual tests is a problem for me at the moment. I can't run TUI tests on my laptop, because they all fail with `address already in use` (calls `helpers.new_pipename()` which eventually calls `uv_pipe_bind()` which fails with -48). I can reproduce this on two Catalina systems, so I guess this is just another OS-specific bug. (There are a few open [macOS-related libuv issues](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Amacos) and at least one of them is specific to Catalina.)

Anyway, it works in my Ubuntu VM, but I'm unsure about my approach. The `received` variable is always `nil`, so it probably doesn't work this way. Ideas?
Do we still want to try and push this through? @mhinz can you rebase?
Hmm, this would be useful in some limited form, that could be expanded later... at least we need a tracking issue if this PR will not be continued.

title: [WIP] vterm: forward unknown CSI/DCS/OSC sequences to outer terminal
